questions.question: For 2024, the annual gift tax exclusion per donee is:
questions.explanation: The annual gift tax exclusion for 2024 is $18,000 per donee (indexed for inflation). A married couple can give $36,000 per donee if gift-splitting is elected. Gifts within the exclusion do not require filing Form 709 (unless gift-splitting applies).
questions.tip: 2024 annual exclusion = $18,000 per donee. Married couples = $36,000 with gift-splitting.

questions.question: The unified credit for estate and gift tax purposes shelters transfers up to what amount (basic exclusion amount) for 2024?
questions.explanation: For 2024, the basic exclusion amount is $13,610,000 per person (indexed for inflation under TCJA). A married couple can transfer up to $27,220,000 tax-free using portability. This amount is scheduled to revert to approximately $6-7 million in 2026 when TCJA expires.
questions.tip: 2024 exemption = $13.61M. TCJA sunsets 2026 - exemption will approximately halve.

questions.question: The annual gift tax exclusion applies only to gifts of:

options.A: Real property
options.B: Cash only
options.C: Present interests
options.D: Future interests

questions.explanation: The annual exclusion applies only to gifts of present interests (an unrestricted right to immediate use, possession, or enjoyment). Future interests (gifts where enjoyment is delayed) do not qualify for the annual exclusion, even if they are otherwise complete gifts.
questions.tip: Annual exclusion = present interest only. Gifts to trusts may need Crummey powers for exclusion.

questions.question: The estate tax marital deduction allows:

options.A: A $500,000 deduction for transfers to spouses
options.B: An unlimited deduction for qualifying transfers to a surviving spouse
options.C: A deduction only if the surviving spouse is a U.S. citizen
options.D: Both B and C (unlimited but with citizenship requirement)

questions.explanation: The marital deduction provides an unlimited estate tax deduction for qualifying transfers to a surviving spouse who is a U.S. citizen. If the surviving spouse is not a citizen, the marital deduction is only available through a qualified domestic trust (QDOT).
questions.tip: Unlimited marital deduction requires U.S. citizen spouse. Non-citizen → use QDOT.

questions.question: Portability allows a surviving spouse to:

options.A: Transfer assets to the deceased spouse's estate
options.B: Use the deceased spouse's unused exemption (DSUE)
options.C: Avoid filing an estate tax return
options.D: Claim an additional marital deduction

questions.explanation: Portability allows the surviving spouse to use the deceased spouse's unused exemption (DSUE) amount, effectively doubling the exemption for married couples. A timely filed estate tax return (Form 706) is required to elect portability, even if no tax is owed.
questions.tip: Portability = use deceased spouse's unused exemption. Requires timely Form 706 filing to elect.

questions.question: Gift-splitting allows married couples to:

options.A: Make separate gifts from each spouse's assets
options.B: Treat a gift by one spouse as made one-half by each spouse
options.C: Avoid all gift tax on any amount
options.D: Split the annual exclusion between donees

questions.explanation: Gift-splitting (Section 2513) allows a gift made by one spouse to be treated as made one-half by each spouse. This doubles the annual exclusion ($36,000 per donee in 2024) and allows both spouses' unified credits to be used. Both spouses must consent, requiring Form 709.
questions.tip: Gift-splitting doubles exclusion and uses both spouses' credits. Requires both to file Form 709.

questions.question: Payments made directly to an educational institution for tuition are:

options.A: Subject to gift tax and use unified credit
options.B: Excluded from gift tax without limit under Section 2503(e)
options.C: Limited to the annual exclusion amount
options.D: Deductible from the donor's income tax

questions.explanation: Payments made directly to educational institutions for tuition (not room/board/books) and directly to medical providers for medical care are excluded from gift tax without limit under Section 2503(e). These payments are in addition to the annual exclusion.
questions.tip: Direct tuition/medical payments = unlimited exclusion. Must pay institution/provider directly.

questions.question: The gross estate for estate tax purposes includes:

options.A: Only assets passing through probate
options.B: Only assets titled in the decedent's name
options.C: All assets in which the decedent had an interest, including life insurance and retirement accounts
options.D: Only assets located in the United States

questions.explanation: The gross estate includes all property in which the decedent had an interest at death, regardless of how it passes. This includes probate assets, jointly held property, life insurance proceeds (if decedent owned the policy), retirement accounts, revocable trusts, and property over which decedent had a general power of appointment.
questions.tip: Gross estate = broad inclusion. Life insurance, joint property, retirement accounts all included.

questions.question: Property included in a decedent's gross estate receives a basis equal to:

options.A: The decedent's adjusted basis (carryover)
options.B: Fair market value at date of death or alternate valuation date
options.C: Zero
options.D: Original cost to the decedent

questions.explanation: Property included in the gross estate receives a stepped-up (or stepped-down) basis to fair market value at date of death (or alternate valuation date if elected). This eliminates income tax on unrealized appreciation during the decedent's lifetime.
questions.tip: Death = FMV basis. Wipes out all unrealized gain. Key planning consideration.

questions.question: The generation-skipping transfer (GST) tax applies to transfers to beneficiaries who are:

options.A: One generation below the transferor
options.B: Two or more generations below the transferor (skip persons)
options.C: The transferor's siblings
options.D: Non-family members only

questions.explanation: The GST tax applies to transfers to skip persons - generally those two or more generations below the transferor (grandchildren, great-grandchildren). The tax prevents avoidance of estate/gift tax at the intermediate generation. The GST exemption equals the estate exemption ($13,610,000 in 2024).
questions.tip: GST = transfers to skip persons (2+ generations below). Same exemption as estate tax.

questions.question: Crummey powers allow gifts to trusts to qualify for the annual exclusion by:

options.A: Converting future interests to present interests through withdrawal rights
options.B: Reducing the trust corpus
options.C: Allowing the trustee to make distributions
options.D: Establishing the trust as a grantor trust

questions.explanation: Crummey powers give beneficiaries a temporary right to withdraw contributed amounts, converting what would be a future interest (not eligible for annual exclusion) into a present interest (eligible). Beneficiaries typically allow the withdrawal right to lapse, and the gift remains in trust.
questions.tip: Crummey withdrawal power = present interest → annual exclusion available for trust gifts.

questions.question: Life insurance owned by an irrevocable life insurance trust (ILIT) is excluded from the insured's estate if:

options.A: The insured transfers an existing policy to the trust
options.B: The trust has owned the policy for more than 3 years at death
options.C: The insured is a beneficiary of the trust
options.D: The trust uses the annual exclusion only

questions.explanation: Life insurance is excluded from the insured's estate if the ILIT owns the policy and the insured has no incidents of ownership. If an existing policy is transferred to an ILIT, the insured must survive 3 years after transfer (Section 2035). Having the trust purchase a new policy avoids this issue.
questions.tip: ILIT excludes insurance from estate. Transfer existing policy → 3-year survival requirement.

questions.question: Minority and marketability discounts reduce the gift/estate tax value of:

options.A: Publicly traded securities only
options.B: Real estate only
options.C: Closely-held business interests
options.D: Cash equivalents

questions.explanation: Minority discounts (for lack of control) and marketability discounts (for lack of a ready market) can significantly reduce the gift/estate tax value of closely-held business interests, family limited partnerships, and LLCs. These discounts can range from 15% to 40% or more combined.
questions.tip: Valuation discounts = minority + marketability. Significant tax savings on family business transfers.

questions.question: Section 6166 allows deferral of estate tax when:

options.A: The estate includes any business interest
options.B: A closely-held business exceeds 35% of the adjusted gross estate
options.C: The estate elects alternate valuation
options.D: The estate has insufficient liquidity

questions.explanation: Section 6166 allows deferral of estate tax attributable to closely-held business interests if the business exceeds 35% of the adjusted gross estate. Interest-only payments can be made for 4 years, followed by up to 10 annual installments. Special 2% interest rate applies to a portion of deferred tax.
questions.tip: Section 6166: closely-held business >35% of estate. 14-year payout option with favorable interest rate.

questions.question: A grantor retained annuity trust (GRAT) is designed to:

options.A: Provide income to charities
options.B: Transfer appreciation to beneficiaries while minimizing gift tax
options.C: Avoid all estate and gift taxes
options.D: Provide lifetime income to beneficiaries

questions.explanation: A GRAT transfers assets to an irrevocable trust while the grantor retains annuity payments for a term. The taxable gift is the remainder value (gift minus retained annuity). If assets appreciate more than the Section 7520 rate, the excess passes to beneficiaries gift-tax free. Zeroed-out GRATs are popular.
questions.tip: GRAT transfers appreciation above hurdle rate tax-free. Risk: grantor must survive the term.

questions.question: The alternate valuation date (6 months after death) may be elected if:

options.A: It increases estate value
options.B: It decreases both the gross estate value and estate tax liability
options.C: The estate includes real property
options.D: The executor prefers a later valuation

questions.explanation: The alternate valuation date (6 months after death) may be elected only if it decreases both the value of the gross estate AND the estate tax liability (after credits). If either would increase, the election is not available. Property distributed before 6 months is valued at distribution date.
questions.tip: Alternate valuation: only if BOTH gross estate AND tax decrease. Not for basis step-up planning alone.

questions.question: A gift is complete for gift tax purposes when the donor has:

options.A: Signed a gift document
options.B: Parted with dominion and control so as to leave no power to change its disposition
options.C: Received consideration from the donee
options.D: Filed Form 709

questions.explanation: A gift is complete when the donor has so parted with dominion and control as to leave no power to change its disposition. Retained powers (to revoke, change beneficiaries, or control investment) may cause the gift to be incomplete. Completion timing affects annual exclusion year.
questions.tip: Complete gift = donor relinquishes dominion and control. Retained powers → incomplete gift.

questions.question: A general power of appointment causes property to be included in the power holder's estate because:

options.A: The power holder created the trust
options.B: The power holder can appoint the property to themselves, their estate, or creditors
options.C: The power holder receives income from the property
options.D: The power is exercised at death

questions.explanation: A general power of appointment (power to appoint to self, one's estate, or creditors) causes inclusion in the gross estate under Section 2041, whether or not exercised. A limited (special) power (cannot appoint to self, estate, or creditors) does not cause estate inclusion.
questions.tip: General power = can appoint to self → estate inclusion. Limited/special power = no estate inclusion.

questions.question: A qualified personal residence trust (QPRT) allows the grantor to:

options.A: Transfer a residence to children at a reduced gift tax value while retaining the right to live there
options.B: Exclude the residence from the gross estate automatically
options.C: Receive a stepped-up basis on the residence
options.D: Avoid capital gains on the ultimate sale

questions.explanation: A QPRT transfers a personal residence to an irrevocable trust while the grantor retains the right to live there for a term of years. The taxable gift is the remainder value (discounted for retained use). If the grantor survives the term, the residence passes to beneficiaries with a reduced transfer tax cost.
questions.tip: QPRT = discounted gift of residence. Must survive term or full value included in estate.

questions.question: A Section 303 redemption allows an estate to redeem stock to pay estate taxes and receive:

options.A: Ordinary income treatment
options.B: Capital gain treatment
options.C: Exchange (sale) treatment rather than dividend treatment
options.D: Tax-free distribution treatment

questions.explanation: Section 303 allows an estate (or beneficiary) to redeem stock from a closely-held corporation to pay estate taxes, funeral, and administration expenses and receive exchange (capital gain) treatment rather than dividend treatment. The stock must exceed 35% of the adjusted gross estate.
questions.tip: Section 303: stock redemption for estate taxes = exchange treatment, not dividend. Requires >35% test.

questions.question: A charitable lead trust provides:

options.A: Income to charity for a term, with remainder to family
options.B: Income to family for a term, with remainder to charity
options.C: All income and principal to charity
options.D: Income to the grantor with remainder to charity

questions.explanation: A charitable lead trust (CLT) pays income to charity for a specified term, with the remainder passing to non-charitable beneficiaries (typically family). The CLT provides a gift/estate tax deduction for the present value of the charitable lead interest, reducing transfer taxes on the remainder.
questions.tip: CLT = charity first, family remainder. Opposite of CRT. Good for transferring appreciation.

questions.question: A trust that is fully exempt from GST tax (inclusion ratio of zero) is achieved by:

options.A: Making distributions only to non-skip persons
options.B: Allocating sufficient GST exemption to equal the transfer value
options.C: Establishing the trust as a grantor trust
options.D: Limiting trust duration to 21 years

questions.explanation: A trust's inclusion ratio determines GST tax. An inclusion ratio of zero (no GST tax) requires allocating GST exemption equal to the property's value at transfer. The applicable fraction equals GST exemption allocated divided by value of property transferred. Timely allocation is important to avoid inclusion ratio issues.
questions.tip: Zero inclusion ratio = full GST exemption allocation. Timely allocation avoids later problems.

questions.question: Under Section 2036, a transfer with retained life estate or retained right to income causes estate inclusion because:

options.A: The transfer was not completed during life
options.B: The decedent retained an interest causing the property to pass at death
options.C: Gift tax was not paid on the transfer
options.D: The property was transferred to a family member

questions.explanation: Section 2036 includes in the gross estate property transferred during life if the decedent retained: (1) possession/enjoyment or income from the property for life, or (2) the right to designate who will possess or enjoy the property. This applies to many retained interest arrangements.
questions.tip: Section 2036: retain life interest → full estate inclusion (despite gift tax already paid).

questions.question: An intentionally defective grantor trust (IDGT) is designed so that:

options.A: The trust is included in the grantor's estate
options.B: Income is taxed to the grantor but the trust is excluded from the estate
options.C: All income is tax-exempt
options.D: The grantor receives annuity payments

questions.explanation: An IDGT is structured so the grantor is treated as the owner for income tax purposes (pays tax on trust income) but the trust is complete for gift/estate tax purposes (excluded from estate). This allows tax-free growth as the grantor's payment of income tax is an additional tax-free gift.
questions.tip: IDGT = grantor trust for income tax, complete gift for transfer tax. Grantor paying tax = additional tax-free gift.

questions.question: Section 2035 brings back into the gross estate:

options.A: All gifts made within 3 years of death
options.B: Life insurance transferred within 3 years of death and gift taxes paid on gifts made within 3 years
options.C: Only gifts exceeding $1 million
options.D: Gifts to charities within 3 years of death

questions.explanation: Section 2035 includes in the gross estate: (1) life insurance transferred within 3 years of death (or incidents of ownership released), and (2) gift taxes paid on any gifts made within 3 years of death (gross-up rule). Most other gifts are not brought back, but GRAT/QPRT failures are covered by other sections.
questions.tip: 3-year rule: life insurance transfers and gift taxes paid. Regular gifts not brought back under 2035.

questions.question: Section 2032A allows special use valuation for:

options.A: Any real property in the estate
options.B: Closely-held business real property and farms valued at actual use rather than highest and best use
options.C: Personal residences only
options.D: Property transferred to charity

questions.explanation: Section 2032A allows qualifying farm and closely-held business real estate to be valued at its actual use rather than highest and best use (which would be higher). The reduction is capped ($1,390,000 in 2024). Recapture tax applies if the property is sold or use changes within 10 years.
questions.tip: Section 2032A: farm/business real property valued at actual use. 10-year recapture if use changes.

questions.question: A 'net gift' arrangement, where the donee agrees to pay the gift tax, results in:

options.A: A larger taxable gift
options.B: A smaller taxable gift (reduced by gift tax paid by donee)
options.C: Complete elimination of gift tax
options.D: Ordinary income to the donor

questions.explanation: In a net gift, the donee agrees to pay the gift tax, reducing the taxable gift by the amount of tax paid (circular calculation). If the tax paid by the donee exceeds the donor's basis in the property, the donor may recognize gain to that extent (Diedrich v. Commissioner).
questions.tip: Net gift reduces gift value but may trigger gain to donor if tax exceeds basis.

questions.question: A dynasty trust is designed to:

options.A: Terminate after 21 years
options.B: Provide for multiple generations while avoiding estate and GST tax at each generation
options.C: Distribute all income currently to beneficiaries
options.D: Qualify for the marital deduction

questions.explanation: Dynasty trusts are designed to last for multiple generations (potentially perpetually in states without Rule Against Perpetuities) while avoiding estate tax at each generation. Properly structured with GST exemption, the trust corpus is never subject to estate or GST tax regardless of growth.
questions.tip: Dynasty trust: multi-generational wealth transfer. Use GST exemption. Perpetual in some states.

questions.question: A qualified terminable interest property (QTIP) trust qualifies for the marital deduction while allowing:

options.A: The donor spouse to retain the property
options.B: The surviving spouse unlimited access to principal
options.C: The donor spouse to control ultimate disposition to remaindermen
options.D: Avoidance of estate tax on the survivor's death

questions.explanation: A QTIP trust provides the surviving spouse with all income for life (mandatory) while allowing the deceased spouse to control who receives the property at the survivor's death. The property qualifies for the marital deduction at the first death but is included in the survivor's estate (or taxed to survivor's estate under Section 2044).
questions.tip: QTIP = marital deduction + control remainder. Surviving spouse must get all income for life.

questions.question: A spousal lifetime access trust (SLAT) allows couples to:

options.A: Avoid all estate taxes
options.B: Use the gift tax exemption while retaining indirect access through the spouse beneficiary
options.C: Create a joint trust with both spouses as grantors
options.D: Receive income tax deductions for trust contributions

questions.explanation: A SLAT allows a married person to create an irrevocable trust for the benefit of their spouse (and potentially descendants), using their gift tax exemption to remove assets from their estate while retaining indirect access through the spouse beneficiary. Both spouses can create SLATs but must avoid reciprocal trust doctrine issues.
questions.tip: SLAT = use exemption + indirect access via spouse. Avoid reciprocal trusts with different terms.

questions.question: Family limited partnerships (FLPs) and LLCs are used in estate planning to:

options.A: Avoid all transfer taxes
options.B: Facilitate discounted transfers of minority interests to family members
options.C: Eliminate income tax on business operations
options.D: Qualify assets for the marital deduction

questions.explanation: FLPs and LLCs allow business owners to transfer minority, non-controlling interests to family members at discounted values (minority and marketability discounts). The senior generation retains control through general partner/manager interests while transferring value at reduced gift tax cost.
questions.tip: FLP/LLC transfers: minority interests qualify for discounts. IRS scrutinizes deathbed transfers and lack of business purpose.

questions.question: Unless the will provides otherwise, estate taxes are typically apportioned:

options.A: Equally among all beneficiaries
options.B: According to state law apportionment statutes
options.C: Only against probate assets
options.D: Paid entirely from the residuary estate

questions.explanation: Estate tax apportionment depends on state law and the decedent's will. Many states have equitable apportionment statutes that allocate tax burden proportionally among beneficiaries. Without direction, taxes may be paid from the residue (burdening residuary beneficiaries) or apportioned. Planning documents should address apportionment.
questions.tip: Tax apportionment = state law default unless will specifies. Important planning consideration.

questions.question: The key difference between a charitable remainder annuity trust (CRAT) and charitable remainder unitrust (CRUT) is:

options.A: CRATs allow additional contributions; CRUTs do not
options.B: CRATs pay fixed amounts; CRUTs pay a percentage of annually revalued trust assets
options.C: CRUTs provide larger charitable deductions
options.D: CRATs must distribute all income annually

questions.explanation: A CRAT pays a fixed annuity amount (determined at creation, at least 5% of initial value). A CRUT pays a fixed percentage of trust assets revalued annually (at least 5%), so payments fluctuate with trust value. CRUTs allow additional contributions; CRATs do not.
questions.tip: CRAT = fixed payment. CRUT = percentage of revalued assets. CRUT allows additions, CRAT doesn't.

questions.question: An installment sale to a grantor trust is an estate planning technique because:

options.A: No gain is recognized on the sale
options.B: The sale removes future appreciation from the estate while providing income to the seller
options.C: The trust receives a stepped-up basis
options.D: Estate taxes are eliminated on the transferred property

questions.explanation: Selling assets to a grantor trust for an installment note removes future appreciation from the seller's estate. Since the trust is a grantor trust, no gain is recognized on the sale (disregarded transaction). Interest payments may be below AFR if structured properly. The note replaces the asset value in the estate.
questions.tip: Installment sale to IDGT = freeze value + no gain recognition (grantor trust). Appreciation benefits beneficiaries.

questions.question: The potential 'clawback' issue with large gifts before 2026 relates to:

options.A: Gifts being returned to the estate
options.B: Estate tax calculated on the reduced post-2025 exemption recapturing benefit of prior higher exemption
options.C: Gift tax being assessed on previously exempt gifts
options.D: Loss of stepped-up basis on gifted property

questions.explanation: When the exemption reverts to approximately $6-7 million in 2026, estates that used the higher exemption for lifetime gifts could theoretically owe estate tax on the difference. IRS regulations provide anti-clawback protection - the higher exemption will be used to calculate estate tax if the exemption was higher when gifts were made.
questions.tip: Anti-clawback rules protect large gifts made under higher TCJA exemption. Use it or lose it before 2026.
